bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Howard A. Kelly, November 10, 1904

div1.p: Kean forwards Kelly information about Walter Reed for Kelly's biography.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Howard A. Kelly, November 10, 1904
div1.opener:
WAR DEPARTMENT,
OFFICE OF THE SURGEON GENERAL,
Washington.
November 10, 1904.
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
Dr. Howard A. Kelly,
1418 Eutaw Place,
Baltimore, Maryland.
My dear Dr. Kelly:
div1.p:
Yours dated the 7th but postmarked the 10th has just reached me,
and it will give me the greatest pleasure to assist you in any way I
can in collecting material for a “Life of Walter Reed.”

The stock of material with regard to his personal life is very
slender and was pretty well drawn upon by Major McCaw in his charming
little sketch which is being circulated by the Reed Memorial Association
and which doubtless you have read.

With regard to yellow fever work:- I will send you a collection
of all the monographs. If you are going to give a history of the epi-
demics of yellow fever in this country, however, you will find a com-
plete account of the earlier ones in La Roche's monumental work. If
you want any other bibliography of yellow fever, I am sure that McCaw,
who is the Librarian of the Surgeon General's Office, will be glad to
furnish it to you.

With regard to the personal charm and attractiveness of Dr. Reed,
it is hard to furnish “data”, though I have the liveliest recollection
and appreciation of these characteristics of his and attempted to de-
scribe them in the short address that I made at the memorial meeting of
the Medical Society of the District of Columbia shortly after his death.
Dr. Howard A. Kelly.
11-10-1904.
2.
FROM DR. HOWARD A. KELLY
I suppose you have the addresses made at that meeting as far as they
were printed. Unfortunately, the ost striking ones, those of Dr.
Welch and General Wood, were extemporaneous and as there was no reporter
there, were not obtained.

I will have Dr. Carroll get you together a collection of Reed's
monographs and will send you whatever I have whenever you write for it.
I will ask you, however, to return me the things I send, as I have no
duplicates and want to keep them as memorials of one of the most bril-
liant and one of the most delightful friends I have ever had.

On account of Dr. Carroll's intimate association with Dr. Reed
in the later years of his life he can perhaps furnish you other material
which will be suitable, and will, I am sure, be glad to assist you if
you call on him.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely, your friend, J.R. Kean.
Major, Surgeon, U. S. Army.
